dt: {bc}to cause (someone) to experience a strong feeling of enjoyable excitement

dt.t: The news {wi}thrilled{/wi} him.
a performance that {wi}thrilled{/wi} the crowd
It's just one of the 35 breathtaking stunts the 47-year-old daredevil pilot uses to {wi}thrill{/wi} spectators at airshows across the country.

dt: {bc}to experience a surge of excitement and pleasure

dt.t: They {wi}thrilled{/wi} to the sound of his voice.
She remembers that her father {wi}thrilled{/wi} to see his daughter's name in print …
From the beginning, Americans {wi}thrilled{/wi} to the Hubble's potential to do dramatic science, to take us intellectually where no one has gone before.
Kit {wi}thrilled{/wi} at the sight of the familiar red coats.

dt: {bc}to move or pass so as to cause a sudden wave of emotion

dt.t: … a faint cold fear {wi}thrills{/wi} through my veins …
… the very rocks seem to {wi}thrill{/wi} with life.

et: Middle English {it}thirlen, thrillen{/it} to pierce, from Old English {it}thyrlian{/it}, from {it}thyrel{/it} hole, from {it}thurh{/it} through {ma}{mat|through:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to cause (someone) to experience a strong feeling of enjoyable excitement
to experience a surge of excitement and pleasure
to move or pass so as to cause a sudden wave of emotion

dt: {bc}a feeling of great excitement or happiness

dt.t: The {wi}thrill{/wi} isn't gone from our marriage after all this time.
the {wi}thrill{/wi} of discovery/victory
"The most fun thing I've done so far," [Dorothy] Parke reports, "is put my foot through a window. It was only breakaway glass; but it was my first stunt, and it gave me such a {wi}thrill{/wi}."

dt: {bc}a tingling of or as if of the nerves produced by a sudden emotional reaction

dt.t: a {wi}thrill{/wi} of horror
a {wi}thrill{/wi} of pride/pleasure/anticipation
Harry felt a {wi}thrill{/wi} of dread: He was about to pay for what had just happened, he was sure of it.

dt: {bc}a very exciting or enjoyable event or experience

dt.t: What a {wi}thrill{/wi} it was to see the Queen!
a movie with a lot of {phrase}thrills and chills{/phrase} {gloss}=exciting and frightening parts{/gloss}
the {phrase}thrills and spills{/phrase} of skateboarding
He had always fancied himself as having a fine voice, and now to hear it from his wife's own lips was a real {wi}thrill{/wi}.

shortdef: a feeling of great excitement or happiness
a tingling of or as if of the nerves produced by a sudden emotional reaction
a very exciting or enjoyable event or experience

dt.t: Seeing the Queen was the {it}thrill of her life{/it}.

shortdef: an experience that is very exciting

dt: {bc}a very exciting ride (such as a roller coaster) at an amusement park

dt.t: The campaign has been a {it}thrill ride{/it} from the beginning.

shortdef: a very exciting ride (such as a roller coaster) at an amusement park —often used figuratively

dt.t: He likes to harass the neighbor's dog as a {it}cheap thrill{/it}.

shortdef: a minor thing done for entertainment
